newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: EMU delay can only be considered in late 97 - Clarke.
newsitem.headline: EMU delay can only be considered in late 97 - Clarke.

text.p: Any serious consideration of a delay in the timetable for Europe's single currency can only arise later this year, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kenneth Clarke, said on Saturday.
"My serious judgment is that it will not be possible to take things further until the autumn of this year," Clarke told reporters after a meeting of European Union finance ministers.
At that point there would be sufficient data available about the economic performance of EU countries to determine whether such a decision was needed.

Clarke, reaffirming his view that it would be unlikely for the common currency to be launched on schedule in 1999, said he had not encountered any serious consideration of a postponement among EU ministers.
"I assure you I have not had a conversation (about delay) with any minister," he said.

Attending the same briefing, Bank of England governor Eddie George said a credible delay to monetary union could only be achieved if governments persuaded financial markets that they would continue stable economic policies after the postponement.
Clarke also said that public thinking in western Europe was misguided to the extent it linked tough budgetary measures solely with the preconditions of monetary union.
Such policies had to be undertaken by all governments irrespective of the demands of a single currency, he said.
EU ministers on Saturday agreed that a decision on which countries join the launch of a single currency would be taken in late-April or early May 1998.
